text: प्रथमोऽध्यायः
en_dmt: "First Chapter.  "

text: रागादिरोगान् सततानुषक्तान् अशेषकायप्रसृतानशेषान्। औत्सुक्यमोहाऽरतिदाञ्जघान योऽपूर्ववैद्याय नमोऽस्तु तस्मै॥
en_dmt: "Homage to that unparalleled physician who has slain all the diseases of passion (rāga), etc., which are constantly clinging, spread throughout the entire body, and give rise to eagerness, delusion (moha), and discontent (arati).  "

text: आयुः कामयमानेन धर्मार्थसुखसाधनम्। आयुर्वेदोपदेशेषु विधेयः परमादरः॥
en_dmt: "[For] him who wishes a long life leading to virtue (dharma), wealth (artha), and happiness (sukha), the utmost attention should be paid to the precepts of medical science (Āyurveda). (आयुः कामयमानेन धर्मार्थसुखसाधनम् । आयुर्वेदोपदेशेषु विधेयः परमादरः ॥)  "

text: ब्रह्मास्मृत्वाऽऽयुषो वेदं प्रजापतिमजिग्रहत्। सोऽश्विनौ तौ सहस्राक्षं सोऽत्रिपुत्रादिकान्मुनीन्॥ तेऽग्निवेषादिकांस्ते तु पृथक् तन्त्राणि तेनिरे। तेभ्योऽतिविप्रकीर्णेभ्यः प्रायः सारतरोच्चयः॥
en_dmt: "Brahmā, remembering the Veda of longevity, imparted it to Prajāpati. He [imparted it] to the Aśvins, they to Sahasrākṣa (Indra), he to the sages beginning with the sons of Atri. They [taught it] to Agniveśa, etc. They, however, composed their works separately. Because these [were] too widely scattered, there is made from them a collection for the most part of very essential matter.  "

text: क्रियतेऽष्टाङ्गहृदयं नातिसंक्षेपविस्तरम्। कायबालग्रहोर्ध्वाङ्गशल्यदंष्ट्राजरावृषान्॥
en_dmt: "The Aṣṭāṅgahṛdaya is composed, [which is] without too much brevity or prolixity, [and which treats] kāya, bāla, graha, ūrdhvāṅga, śalya, daṃṣṭrā, jarā, and vṛṣa.  "

text: अष्टावङ्गानि तस्याहुश्चिकित्सा येषु संश्रिता। वायुः पित्तं कफश्चेति त्रयो दोषाः समासतः॥
en_dmt: "They say that it has eight branches in which healing is based. *Vāta*, *pitta*, and *kapha*—these are, in brief, the three *doṣas*.  "

text: विकृताविकृता देहं घ्नन्ति ते वर्तयन्ति च। ते व्यापिनाऽपि ह्रृन्नाभ्योरधोमध्योर्ध्वसंश्रयाः॥
en_dmt: "Depending on whether they are changed or unchanged [in their state], they respectively destroy and sustain the body. Though spreading everywhere, they are seated respectively below, between, and above [the region between the] breast and navel. (विकृताविकृता देहं घ्नन्ति ते वर्तयन्ति च । ते व्यापिनो ऽपि हृन्नाभ्योर् अधोमध्योर्ध्वसंश्रयाः ॥)  "

text: वयोहोरात्रिभुक्तानां तेऽन्तमध्यादिगाः क्रमात्। तैर्भवेद्विषमस्तीक्ष्णो मन्दश्चाग्निः समैः समः॥
en_dmt: "Of those, youth, the hours of the night, and [the time] after meals are, respectively, the end, middle, and beginning. From them, the *agni* is *viṣama*, *tīkṣṇa*, and *manda*; with the balanced ones, it is balanced (*sama*).  "

text: कोष्ठः क्रूरो मृदुर्मध्यो मध्यः स्यात्तैः समैरपि। शुक्रार्तवस्थैर्जन्मादौ विषेणेव विषक्रिमे॥
en_dmt: "The belly may be hard, soft, or normal respectively; [that is,] normal only when they are balanced. Just as a poison worm [is produced] from semen and the menstrual fluid when they are in the womb, or from poison.  "

text: तैश्च तिस्रः प्रकृतयो हीनमध्योत्तमाः पृथक्। समधातुः समस्तासु श्रेष्ठा, निन्द्या द्विदोषजाः॥
en_dmt: "Those [doṣas] have three *prakṛtis*: deficient (*hīna*), moderate (*madhya*), and increased (*uttama*), respectively. That [constitution] in which the elements are balanced (*samadhātuḥ*) is the best of all; [those] originating [in only] two *doṣas* (*dvedoṣajāḥ*) are to be regarded as inferior (*nindyā*).  "

text: तत्र रूक्षो लघुः खरः सूक्ष्मश्चलोऽनिलः। पित्तं सस्नेहतीक्ष्णोष्णे लघु विस्रं सरं द्रवम्॥
en_dmt: "Among the humors, wind is rough, light, pungent, subtle, and volatile; choler [is] slightly unctuous, violent, hot, light, musty, liquid, and flowing.  "

text: स्निग्धाः शीतो गुरुर्मन्दः श्लक्ष्णोमृत्स्नः स्थिरः कफः। संसर्गः सन्निपातश्च तद्द्वि-त्रि-त्रिक्षयकोपतः॥
en_dmt: "Phlegm [is] unctuous, cold, heavy, sluggish, smooth, slimy, [and] stable. Association and combination [of the doṣas occur] due to the aggravation of two, three, or all three [doṣas].  "

text: रसाऽसृङ्भांसमेदोऽस्थिमज्जशुक्राणि धातवः। 'सप्तदूष्याः' मला-मूत्रशकृत्स्वेदादयोऽपि च॥
en_dmt: "The *dhātus* are *rasa*, *asṛṅ* (blood), *māṃsa* (muscle), *medas* (fat), *asthi* (bone), *majjā* (marrow), and *śukra* (semen). [These] seven [tissues are] prone to vitiation. Waste products such as urine, feces, sweat, etc. [are also prone to vitiation].  "

text: वृद्धिः समानैः सर्वेषां विपरीतैर्विपर्ययः। रसाः स्वाद्वम्ललवणतिक्तोषणकषायकाः॥
en_dmt: "There is increase of all [humors, tissues, and waste products] by homogeneous [substances]; by opposite [substances, there is] the opposite [effect, i.e., decrease]. The tastes are sweet ( *svādu*), sour (*amla*), salty (*lavaṇa*), bitter (*tikta*), pungent (*uṣaṇa*), and astringent (*kaṣāyaka*).  "

text: षड्, द्रव्यमाश्रितास्ते च यथापूर्वं बलावहाः। तत्राऽऽद्या मारुतं घ्नन्ति त्रयस्तिक्तादयः कफम् ।।
en_dmt: "They, relying on the six substances, are powerful as before. Therein, the first three [tastes, i.e. sweet, sour, and salty,] destroy wind [vāta]. The three beginning with bitter [i.e. bitter, astringent, and pungent] [destroy] phlegm [kapha].  "

text: कषायतिक्तमधुराः पित्तमन्ये तु कुर्वते। शमनं कोपनं स्वस्थहितं द्रव्यमिति त्रिधा॥
en_dmt: "Astringent, bitter, and sweet substances increase *pitta*, while others do not. A substance is threefold [in its effect]: pacifying (*śamana*), aggravating (*kopana*), [and] beneficial for normal [health] (*svasthahita*).  "

text: उष्णशीतगुणोत्कर्षात्तत्र वीर्यं द्विधा स्मृतम्। त्रिधा विपाको द्रव्यस्य स्वाद्वम्लकटुकात्मकः॥
en_dmt: "According to the prevalence of the hot or cold qualities, the potency [of a substance] is considered twofold [heating or cooling]. The effect of a substance is threefold: sweet, sour, or pungent in nature.  "

text: गुरु-मन्द-हिम-स्निग्ध-श्लक्ष्ण-सान्द्र-मृदु-स्थिराः। गुणाः ससूक्ष्म-विशदा विंशतिः सविपर्ययाः॥
en_dmt: "Heavy, slow, cold, unctuous, smooth, dense, soft, and stable [are qualities]. The qualities, including subtle and dry [and their opposites], are twenty [in total].  "

text: कालार्थकर्मणां योगो हीन-मिथ्याSतिऽमात्रकः। सम्यग्योगश्च विज्ञेयो रोगाऽऽरोग्यैककारणम्॥
en_dmt: "The connections of time, object, and action are deficient, wrong, and excessive. And the proper connection should be known as the sole cause of disease and health respectively. (सम्यक्-योगश् च विज्ञेयो रोग-आरोग्य-ऐककारणम्)  "

text: रोगस्तु दोषवैषम्यं, दोषसाम्यमरोगता। निजागन्तुविभागेन तत्र रोगा द्विधा स्मृताः॥
en_dmt: "Disease is indeed the imbalance of the humors; balance of the humors [is] health (रोगः तु दोष-वैषम्यं, दोष-साम्यम् अरोगता). Therein, diseases are considered twofold due to their division into endogenous (nija) and exogenous (āgantu) (निजागन्तुविभागेन तत्र रोगा द्वि-धा स्मृताः).  "

text: तेषां कायमनोभेदादधिष्ठानमपि द्विधा। रजस्तमश्च मनसो द्वौ च दोषावुदाहृतौ॥
en_dmt: "On account of the distinction between body (kāya) and mind (manas), their location (adhiṣṭhāna) is also twofold. Passion (rajas) and delusion (tamas) are mentioned as the two mental disorders (doṣau) of the mind (manas).  "

text: दर्शनस्पर्शनप्रश्नैः परीक्षेत च रोगिणम्। रोगं निदान-प्राग्रूपलक्षणोपशयाऽऽप्तिभिः॥
en_dmt: "[The physician] should examine the patient by observation, palpation, and questioning. [He should diagnose] the disease by cause (nidāna), premonitory symptoms (prāgrūpa), symptoms (lakṣaṇa), response [to treatment] (upaśaya), and outcome (āpti).  "

text: भूमिदेहप्रभेदेन देशमाहुरिह द्विधाः जाङ्गलं वातभूयिष्ठमनूपं तु कफोल्वणम्॥
en_dmt: "They say that a region (deśa) here is of two kinds, according to the difference between land (bhūmi) and body (deha): the arid land (jāṅgala) is dominated by wind (vāta), while the marshy land (anūpa) is abundant in phlegm (kapha).  "

text: साधारणं सममलं त्रिधा भूदेशमादिशेत्। क्षणादिर्व्याध्यवस्था च कालो भेषजयोगकृत्॥
en_dmt: "[And] ordinary land [has] balanced humors. Thus, one may define a tract of land as threefold (साधारणं समं मलं त्रिधा भू-देशम् आदिशेत् ।). Time, starting with the moment [kṣaṇa], and the state of the disease determine the suitable time for administering a remedy (क्षणादिर्व्याध्यवस्था च कालो भेषजयोगकृत्).  "

text: शोधनं शमनं चेति समासादौषधं द्विधा। शरीरजानां दोषाणां क्रमेण 'परमौषधम्'॥
en_dmt: "A medicine is broadly classified into two [types]: purificatory (*śodhana*) and palliative (*śamana*). The best medicine for somatic disorders, administered according to the [prescribed] order of the [affected] *doṣas*, is...  "

text: वस्तिर्विरेका वमनं तथा तैलं घृतं मधु। धीधैर्यात्मादिविज्ञानं 'मनोदोषौषधं' परम्॥
en_dmt: "Enema, purgation, and emetics [include] oil, ghee (ghṛta), and honey (madhu). Intelligence, fortitude, and self-knowledge etc. are the best medicines for mental disorders (manodoṣauṣadhaṃ).  "

text: भिषकग् द्रव्याण्युपस्थाता रोगी पादचतुष्टयम्। चिकित्सितस्य निर्दिष्टं, प्रत्येकं तच्चतुर्गुणम्॥
en_dmt: "A physician, medicines (dravyāṇi), an attendant (upasthātā), and the patient (rogī) [constitute] the four components (pādacatustayam). [These are] specified for treatment, each of which is fourfold.  "

text: दक्षस्तीर्थात्तच्शास्त्रार्थो दृष्टकर्मा शुचिर्भिषक। बहुकल्पं बहुगुणं सम्पन्नं योग्यमौषधम्॥
en_dmt: "The physician [should be]: skillful, learned in medical science from a teacher, experienced in practice, and pure (dakṣas tīrthāt tacchāstrārtho dṛṣṭakarmā śucir bhiṣak). The medicine [should be]: versatile, possessing multiple qualities, perfect, and suitable (bahukalpaṃ bahuguṇaṃ sampannaṃ yogyam auṣadham).  "

text: अनुरक्तः शुचिर्दक्षो बुद्धिमान् पऽरिचारकः। आढ्यो रोगी भिषग्वश्यो ज्ञापकः सत्त्ववानपि॥
en_dmt: "The attendant [should be]: devoted (*anuraktaḥ*), pure (*śuciḥ*), skillful (*dakṣo*), and intelligent (*buddhimān*). The patient [should be]: wealthy (*āḍhyo*), obedient to the physician (*bhiṣagvaśyo*), communicative (*jñāpakaḥ*), and courageous (*sattvavān*).  "

text: सर्वौषधक्षमे देहे यूनः पुंसो जितात्मनः। अमर्मगोऽल्पहेत्वग्ररूपरूपोऽनुपद्रवः॥ अतुल्यदूष्यदेशर्तुप्रकृतिः पादसम्पदि। ग्रहेष्वनुगुणेष्वेकदोषमार्गो नवः 'सुखः'॥
en_dmt: "[Considering the case] when the body of a young, self-controlled man is tolerant of all medicines, [and the disease] does not affect a vital spot, [is] of mild cause, indistinct symptoms, and without complications;  [and when] the humours, place, season, and constitution are not excessively vitiated, [and the patient is] in good condition;  and the planets are favorable, [and the disease affects] a single humour and channel, and is recent, [then it is] easy to cure. (ग्रहेषु अनुगुणेषु एकदोषमार्गो नवः सुखः)  "

text: शस्रादिसाधनः कृच्छ्रः सङ्करे च ततो गदः। शेषत्वादायुषो 'याप्यः' पथ्याभ्यासाद्विपरोयये॥
en_dmt: "Kṛcchra [disease] caused by weapons, etc., and then *gada* [disease] due to mixed causes, are *yāpya* [incurable] because of the remaining lifespan, but curable by the practice of wholesome things and the reverse [unwholesome things].  "

text: अनुपक्रम एव स्यात्स्थितोऽत्यन्तविपर्यये। औत्सुक्य-मोहाऽरतिकृद् दृष्टरिष्टोऽक्षनाशनः॥
en_dmt: "There would be no beginning, as it remains in utter perversity. Causing eagerness, delusion, and discontent, it is seen as inauspicious, and destructive of the dice.  "

text: त्यजेदार्तं भिषग्भूपैर्द्विष्टं तेषां द्विषं द्विषम्। हीनोपकरणं व्यग्रमविधेयं गतायुषम्॥ चण्डं शोकातुरं भीरुं कृतघ्नं वैद्यमानिनम्। तन्त्रस्यास्य परं चातो वक्ष्यतेऽध्यायसङ्ग्रहः॥
en_dmt: "[A physician] should abandon a patient who is tormented, hated by kings, who hates them, and is hateful. [He should also abandon a patient who is]: lacking resources, restless, disobedient, nearing the end of his life. Furious, grief-stricken, fearful, ungrateful, and considers himself a physician. Hereafter, moreover, a summary of the chapters of this treatise will be presented. (तन्त्रस्यास्य परं वातो वक्ष्यते ऽध्यायसंग्रहः)  "

text: आयुष्कामदिनर्त्वीहारोगाऽनुत्पादनद्रवाः। अन्नज्ञानाऽन्नसंरक्षामात्राद्रव्यरसाश्रयाः॥ दोषादिज्ञानतद्भेदतच्चिकित्साद्युपक्रमाष्H। शुद्ध्यादिस्नेहन-स्वेद-रेकाऽऽस्थापन-नावनम्॥ धूम-गण्डूष-दृक्सेक-तृप्ति-यन्त्रक-शस्त्रकम्। सिरावधिः शल्यविधिः शस्त्रक्षाराग्निकर्मिकौ॥ सूत्रस्थानमिमेऽध्याया 'त्रिंशत्' 'शरीरमुच्यते'। गर्भावक्रन्तितद्व्यापदङ्गमर्मविभागिकम्॥
en_dmt: "[These include:] 1. The desire for long life (āyuṣkāma), 2-3. Daily (dina) and seasonal (ṛtu) regimens, 4. The prevention of diseases (āroga-anutpādana), 5. Fluids (dravāḥ), 6. Knowledge of food (anna-jñāna), 7. Protection of food (anna-saṃrakṣā), 8. Dosage (mātrā), 9. Substances (dravya), 10. Support of taste (rasāśrayāḥ), 11. Knowledge of the doṣas (doṣādi-jñāna), etc., 12. Their types (tad-bheda), 13. Beginning with their treatment (tac-cikitsā-ādi-upakramāḥ), 14. Purification (śuddhi-ādi), 15. Oleation (snehana), 16. Sudation (sveda), 17. Purgation (reka), 18. Āsthāpana enema, 19. Nasal administration (nāvanam), 20. Smoke (dhūma), 21. Gargling (gaṇḍūṣa), 22. Eye irrigation (dṛk-seka), 23. Satisfaction (tṛpti), 24. Use of instruments (yantraka), 25. Use of surgical instruments (śastraka), 26. Vein puncture (sirāvadhiḥ), 27. Surgical procedures (śalya-vidhiḥ), 28. Surgical and alkali procedures (śastra-kṣāra), 29. Cauterization (agni-karmikau). These thirty chapters are called \"Sūtrasthāna.\" [Chapters on:] 30. Garbhāvakrānti (conception), 31. Its complications (tad-vyāpad), 32. Division of limbs (aṅga-marmavibhāgikam).  "

text: विकृतिर्दुतजं 'षष्ठं' 'निदानं सार्वरोगिकम्'। ज्वारासृक्_श्वासयक्ष्मादिमदाद्यर्शोऽतिसारिणाम्॥
en_dmt: "*Vikṛti* (abnormality) is quickly produced; it is the 'sixth' cause, affecting all diseases.  [It causes] fever, blood disorders, dyspnea, consumption, intoxication, piles, and diarrhea.  "

text: मूत्राघातप्रमेहाणां विद्रध्याद्युदरस्य च पाण्डुकुष्ठानिलार्तानां वातास्रस्य च 'षोडश'॥

text: त्यागः प्रज्ञाऽपराधानामिन्द्रियोपशमः स्मृतिः। देशकालात्मविज्ञानं सद्वृत्तस्यानुवर्तनम्॥ [अथर्वविहिता शान्तिः प्रतिकूलग्रहार्चनम्। भूताद्यस्पर्शनोपायो निर्दिष्टश्च पृथक् पृथक्।।] अनुत्पत्यै समासेन विधिरेष प्रदर्शितः। निजागन्तुविकाराणामुत्पन्नानां च शान्तये॥
en_dmt: "Avoidance of offenses against wisdom, assuagement of the senses, [cultivation of] mindfulness, knowledge of [appropriate] place, time, and [one's own] constitution, [and] imitation of the conduct of sages [are recommended]. "

text: शातोद्भवं दोषचयं वसन्ते विशोधयन् ग्रीष्मजमभ्रकाले। घनात्यये वार्षिकमाशु सम्यक् प्राप्नोति रोगानृतुजान्न जातु॥
en_dmt: "By quickly and properly purging in spring the accumulation of humors produced in the cold season, [purging] in the cloudy season [the accumulation] caused in summer, and [purging] at the disappearance of clouds [the accumulation] formed in the rainy season, one never catches the diseases [usually] caused in these seasons. (शितोद्भवं दोषचयं वसन्ते विशोधयन् । ग्रीष्मजम् अभ्राकाले । घनात्यये वार्षिकम् आशु सम्यक् । प्राप्नोति रोगान् ऋतुजान् न जातु ॥)  "

text: नित्यं हिताहारविहारसेवी समीक्ष्यकारी विषयेष्वसक्तः। दाता समः सत्यपरः क्षमावान् आप्तोपसेवी च भवत्यरोगः॥

"

That which is sprinkled with pure Gaṅgā water, rice that is stainless, kept in silver, Undampened, and uncolored—that is worth drinking; otherwise, it is not.  "

text: सामुद्रं तन्न पातव्यं मासादाश्वयुजाद्विना। ऐन्द्रमम्बुसुपात्रस्थमविपन्नं सदा पिबेत्॥

en_dmt: "Urine derived from cows (go), goats (ajā), sheep (avi), buffaloes (mahiṣī), elephants (gaja), horses (aśva), camels (uṣṭra), and donkeys (khara) increases pitta. en_dmt: "Appetizing and purgative, it eliminates poison, swelling, kapha, and vāta. Appetizing, alleviating kapha and vāta, are the fresh shoots of Cirabilva.  "

en_dmt: "Śatāvarī sprouts are bitter, aphrodisiac, and eliminate the three doṣas.  Bamboo shoots are dry, inflammatory, and increase vāta and pitta.  "

en_dmt: "*Pattūra* improves digestion, is bitter, alleviates splenomegaly, hemorrhoids, kapha, and vāta. It also cures worms, cough, *kaphotkleda*, cough, and *mardaja*.  "

en_dmt: "Kusumbha oil is dry, hot, sour, heavy, mobile, and increases pitta. Mustard oil is heavy, hot, causes constipation and urinary retention, and provokes all doṣas.  "

en_dmt: "That radish which is immature, with indistinct taste, slightly alkaline, and somewhat bitter, alleviates the *doṣas*, is light, slightly hot, and regulates [the *doṣas*]. Again, it greatly alleviates abdominal lump (*gulma*), cough (*kāsa*), consumption (*kṣaya*), dyspnea (*śvāsa*), ulcers (*vraṇa*), diseases of the eyes (*netra*), diseases of the throat (*gala*), fever (*jvara*), loss of digestive power (*agnisāda*), upward movement of *vāta* (*udāvarta*), and rhinitis (*pīnasa*).  "

en_dmt: "It is pungent in taste and post-digestively, heating in potency, and deranges the three doṣas. It is heavy, excessively lubricating, and, if cooked with oil, alleviates vāta.  "

en_dmt: "Dry [ginger] alleviates vāta and śleṣma, while all unripe [ginger] aggravates the doṣas.  Piṇḍālu is pungent, hot, alleviates vāta and kapha, and increases pitta.  "

en_dmt: "Kuṭhera, śigru, surasa, sumukhā, suribhūstṛṇa, phaṇijja, jārjaka, jambīra, and so forth are astringent and cause the flow of saliva. en_dmt: "Hiddhmākāsa-viṣaśvāsa-pārśvaruk-pūtigandhahā. Surasaḥ sumukho nātidāhī garaśophahā.  [It] eliminates hiccups, cough, poison, dyspnea, side pain, and foul smell. *Surasa* and *sumukha* are not very burning and eliminate poison and swelling.  "

en_dmt: "Onions have fewer of those qualities [than garlic], are *śleṣmala* (increasing *kapha*), and only slightly increase *pitta*. They are beneficial for *kapha*, *vāta*, and piles when taken with fomentation.  "

en_dmt: "The pungent leek/gṛñjanaka (Allium ameloprasum Hook.f. non Linn.) is not beneficial for those with deranged pitta. Sūraṇa is appetizing, palatable, alleviates kapha, is clear, and light.  "

en_dmt: "The sweet pomegranate is sweet in taste after digestion, unctuous, astringent, cooling, and heavy. It conquers thirst, cough, exhaustion, dyspnea, hoarseness, consumption due to wounds, aggravated *pitta*, and [balances] the three *doṣas*.  "

en_dmt: "[Food should be] non-antagonistic to bile, not excessively hot or sour, alleviative of wind and phlegm, agreeable, light, unctuous, astringent, appetizing and digestive.  "

en_dmt: "Moca, kharjūra (dates), panasa (jackfruit), nārikela (coconut), and parūṣaka; Āmrāta, tāla, kāśmarya, rājādana, and that born of madhūka; Sauvīra, badara, aṅkolla, phalgū, and that originating from śleṣmātaka; Vātāma (almond), abhiṣuka, akṣoḍa (walnut), mukūlaka, and nikocaka; Urumāṇa and priyāla are nourishing, heavy, and cooling, Alleviating burning sensations, wounds, consumption, and pacifying rakta-pitta; [The fruit is] sweet in taste, unctuous, constipating, and increases kapha and semen. en_dmt: "Saṅgrāhi [is] astringent to urine and feces, good for the throat, and overcomes kapha and pitta.  Vātapittāsrakṛdvālaṃ, baddhāsthi kaphapittakṛt // [It] increases vāta, pitta, and blood, strengthens bones, and increases kapha and pitta.  "

en_dmt: "That which is bitter, sweet, or pungent, or very hot is a remedy for the three doṣas (tridoṣa-jit). The skin [of the fruit] of the citron (mātuluṅga) which is bitter, pungent and unctuous, alleviates vāta.  "

en_dmt: "It is twofold—sweet and sour, cold and hot, heavy, and like pālevata. It is appetizing and quells excessive digestive fire; it is appetizing and sweet like ārūka plums.  "

en_dmt: "That which is cooked quickly ages, [and] is not excessively hot, heavy, or দোষलम्. *Drākṣā* and *Parūṣaka*, if moist and sour, increase *pitta* and *kapha*.  "

en_dmt: "Among fruits, *lakuca* is the worst there, aggravating all *doṣas*. [It is] contaminated by snow, fire, heat, bad wind, poisonous saliva, etc.  "

en_dmt: "One should avoid grains that have been infested with insects, submerged in water, grown in an unsuitable place, or out of season; also grains mixed with other grains, of low potency, or very old.  Likewise, one should avoid grains and vegetables that are dry, overcooked, and not tender, or that have not developed flavor, as well as dried radish.  Generally, one should also avoid unripe fruit, except for *bilva* fruit. All salt should be *viṣyandi*, fine, freshly made, and soft.  "

text: वातघ्नं पाकि तीक्ष्णोष्णं रोचनं कफपित्तकृत्। सैन्धवं तत्र सुस्वादु वृष्यं हृद्यं त्रिदोषनुत्॥

en_dmt: "[Sauvarcala salt] is light, not hot, good for the eyes, does not cause a burning sensation, and kindles the digestive fire; [and] light, pleasing, fragrant, and cleanses belching.  "

text: कटुपाकं विबन्धघ्नं दीपनीयं रुचिप्रदम्। ऊर्ध्वाधः कफवातानुलोमनं दीपनं बिडम्॥
en_dmt: "Viḍa salt is pungent after digestion, alleviates constipation, is a digestive stimulant, improves taste, and normalizes Kapha and Vāta both upwards and downwards. It is also a digestive stimulant (dīpanam).  "

text: विबन्धानाहविष्टम्भशूलगौरवनाशनम्। विपाके स्वादु सामुद्रं गुरु श्लेष्मविवर्धनम्॥

text: क्षारः सर्वश्च परमं तीक्ष्णोष्णः कृमिजिल्लघुः। पित्तासृग्दूषणः पाकी छेद्य-हृद्यो विदारणः॥ अपथ्यः कटुलावण्याच्छुक्रौजः केशचक्षुषाम्। हिङ्गु वातकफानाहशूलघ्नं पित्तकोपनम्॥

Harītakī cures constipation, obstruction of the channels, tumors, stiffness of the thighs, anorexia, and various other diseases caused by kapha and vāta.  "

en_dmt: "The five roots—short [roots], *bṛhatī*, *aṃśumatī*, the two *gokṣuraka*s—, which are astringent, bitter, and hot, conquer *kapha* and *anila*.  "

en_dmt: "Blue lines [appear] in juice, copper-colored in milk, [and] are seen in yogurt. Dark brown, yellowish, black [lines appear] in buttermilk, similar to water in ghee. Dove-colored [lines] occur in whey, black lines in rice water. Black [lines appear] in wine and water, green in honey, and reddish in oil.  The cooking of unripe fruits [is] the cutting up of ripe ones. The wilting and discoloration of wet and dry substances [occur].  There is a reversal of touch for soft and hard things. The splitting of the tips of a garland [and] the appearance of a different smell [occur].  Dark circles [appear] on clothing, the breaking of threads and fringes. Dirtiness [occurs] on metal, pearls, wood, stone, jewels, etc.  Loss of oily touch and luster, but shine in earthenware. A poisoned person [has] a thick, dry mouth, [is] bewildered, [and] looks in all directions.  "

text: स्वेदवेपथुमांस्रस्तो भीतः स्खलति जृम्भते। प्राप्यान्नं सविषं त्वग्निरेकावर्तः स्फुटत्यति॥
en_dmt: "Sweating, trembling, frightened, terrified, he stumbles and yawns. Having obtained poisoned food, the fire, swirling once, bursts exceedingly.  "

text: उत्क्रोशन्ति च दृष्ट्वैतच्छुकदात्यूहसारिकाः। हंसः प्रस्खलति, ग्लानिर्जीवञ्जीवस्य जायते॥ चकोरस्याऽक्षिवैराग्यं, क्रौञ्चस्य स्यान्मदोदयः। कपोतपरभृद्दक्षचक्रवाका जहत्यसून्॥ उद्वेगं याति मार्जारः, शकृन्मुञ्चति वानरः। हृष्येन्मयूरस्तद्दृष्ट्या मन्दतेजो भवेद्विषम्॥ इत्यन्नं विषवज्ज्ञात्वा त्यजेदेवं प्रयत्नतः। यथा तेन विपद्येरन्नपि न क्षुद्रजन्तवः॥
en_dmt: "Seeing this, the Śuka, Dātyūha, and Sārikā birds cry out.  The swan stumbles, and the Jīvañjīva bird becomes weary. en_dmt: "But on being touched, [it causes] itching, burning sensation, heat, fever, pain, blisters, and numbness. Loss of nails and hair, swelling, etc. are the signs of poisoning. en_dmt: "Horripilation, vomiting, burning sensation, obstruction of the eyes and heart, and the accumulation of spots on the body occur when [poison] has reached the small intestine.  One vomits substances of various colors, urinates, and suffers from diarrhea.  Drowsiness, emaciation, pallor, abdominal distention, and loss of strength [also occur]. text: अष्टमोऽध्यायाः। अथातो मात्राशितीयमध्यायं व्याख्यास्यामः। इति ह स्माहुरात्रेयादयो महर्षयः।
en_dmt: "Eighth Chapter. Now, we shall expound the chapter entitled \"Mātrāśitīya Adhyāya\". Thus spoke the great sages Ātreya, etc.  "

text: मात्राशी सर्वकालं स्यान्मात्रा ह्यग्नेः प्रवर्तिका। मात्रां द्रव्याण्यपेक्षन्ते गुरूण्यपि लघून्यपि॥
en_dmt: "One should eat measured amounts at all times, for measure (mātrā) is the promoter of the digestive fire (agni). Heavy as well as light substances depend on measure (mātrā).  "

text: गुरूणामर्धसौहित्य लघूनां नातितृप्तता। मात्राप्रमाणं निर्दिष्टं सुखं यावद्विजीर्यति॥
en_dmt: "Having half-satiety with heavy [foods], [and] not over-satiety with light [foods]. The measure is defined as the amount of happiness that is easily digested.  "

text: भोजनं हीनमात्रं तु न बलोपचयौजसे। सर्वेषां वातरोगाणां हेतुतां च प्रपद्यते॥
en_dmt: "If food is taken in insufficient quantity, it does not lead to increase in strength and vitality; and it becomes the cause of all diseases due to *vāta* (wind).  "

text: अतिमात्रं पुनः सर्वानाशु दोषान् प्रकोपयेत्। पीड्यमाना हि वाताद्या युगपत्तेन कोपिताः॥
en_dmt: "Moreover, an excessive quantity quickly aggravates all the doṣas. Indeed, when afflicted by undigested food, the *vāta* and other *doṣas* are simultaneously provoked.  "

text: आमेनान्नेन दुष्टेन तदेवाऽऽविश्य कुर्वते। विष्टम्भयन्तोऽलसकं च्यावयन्तो विषूचिकाम्॥ अधरोत्तरमार्गाभ्यां सहसैवाजितात्मनः। प्रयाति नोर्ध्वं नाधस्तादाहारो न च पच्यते॥
en_dmt: "Having entered that very thing, they act through impure, undigested food. Obstructing, they cause sluggishness (alasaka); dislodging, they cause cholera (viṣūcikā). For one who has not conquered himself, the food suddenly goes through the upper and lower channels. It goes neither upwards nor downwards, and the food is not digested.  "

text: आमाशयेऽलसीभूतस्तेन सोऽलसकः स्मृतः। विविधैर्वेदनोद्भेदैर्वाय्वादिभृशकोपतः॥
en_dmt: "When the stomach becomes sluggish, it is known as *alasaka*. [It arises] from various piercing pains, due to the great aggravation of wind and other [elements].  "

text: सूचीभिरिव गात्राणि विध्यतीति विषूचिका। तत्र शूलभ्रमाऽऽऽनाहकम्पस्तम्भादयोऽनिलात्॥
en_dmt: "*Viṣūcikā* is like piercing the limbs with needles. There, colic pain, dizziness, abdominal distention, trembling, stiffness, and the like arise from *anila* (wind).  "

text: पित्ताज्ज्वारातिसारान्तर्दाहतृट्_प्रलयादयः। कफाच्छर्द्यङ्गुरुतावाक्सङ्गष्ठीवनादयः॥
en_dmt: "From pitta [arise] fever, diarrhea, internal burning sensation, thirst, destruction, etc. From kapha [arise] vomiting, heaviness of the body, speech impediment, spitting, etc.  "

text: विशेषाद्दुर्बलस्याल्पवह्नेर्वेगविधारिणः। पीडितं मारुतेनान्नं श्लेष्मणा रुद्धमन्तरा।।10। अलसं क्षोभितं दोषैः शल्यत्वेनैव संस्थितम्। शूलादीन् कुरुते तीव्रांश्छर्द्यतीसारवर्जितान्॥ सोऽलसः अत्यर्थदुष्टास्तु दोषा दुष्टाऽऽम-बद्ध-खाः। यान्तस्तिर्यक्तनुं सर्वां दण्डवत्स्तम्भयन्ति चेत्॥
en_dmt: "Especially in the case of the weak, those with feeble digestive fire, and those who suppress urges. Food afflicted by *vāyu* and obstructed internally by *śleṣma*.  [Not found in Tibetan text] Sluggishness, agitated by the *doṣas*, remains like a foreign object. It causes severe pains like colic, but without vomiting or diarrhea. That *alasa* is caused by extremely vitiated *doṣas* that are vitiated, bound by *āma*, and lodged in the channels. If they move sideways and stiffen the entire body like a rod.  "

text: दण्डकालसकं नाम तं त्यजेदाशुकारिणम्। विरुद्धाध्यशनाजीर्णशीलिने विषलक्षणम्॥
en_dmt: "Daṇḍakālasaka, which quickly causes [harm], should be avoided. For one accustomed to unwholesome overeating and indigestion, it is like poison.  "

text: आमदोषं महाघोरं वर्जयेद्विषसंज्ञकम्। विषरूपाशुकारित्वाद्विरुद्धोपक्रमत्वतः॥
en_dmt: "One should avoid the āma-doṣa, which is extremely terrible and known as poison (viṣa), because it acts quickly like poison and because its initial effects are contradictory.  "

text: अथाऽऽममलसीभूतं साध्यं त्वरितमुल्लिखेत्। पीत्वा सोग्रापटुफलं वार्युष्णं योजयेत्ततः॥ स्वेदनं फलवर्ति च मलवातानुलोमनीम्। नाम्यमानानि चाङ्गानि भृशं स्विन्नानि वेष्टयेत्॥
en_dmt: "Then, one should quickly scrape off the undigested *āma* that has become like flaxseed. After drinking warm water mixed with *sogrāpaṭu* fruit, one should apply sudation, a suppository made of fruit, and [measures] that move the feces and *vāta* downwards. Limbs that are being massaged and thoroughly sweated should be wrapped.  "

text: विसूच्यामतिवृद्धायां पार्ष्ण्योर्दाहः प्रशस्यते। तदहश्चोपवास्यैनं विरिक्तवदुपाचरेत्॥
en_dmt: "In a very old woman suffering from cholera (visūcī), burning in the heels is commendable. On that day, one should make her fast and treat her as if she had been purged (virekta).  "

text: तीव्रार्तिरपि नाजीर्णी पिबेच्छूलघ्नमौषधम्। आमसन्नोऽनलो नालं पक्तुं दोषौषधाशनम्॥ निहन्यादपि चैतेषां विभ्रमः सहसाऽऽतुरम्। जीर्णाशने तु भैषज्यं युञ्ज्यात् स्तब्धगुरूदरे॥
en_dmt: "Even with intense pain, one with indigestion should not drink medicine that alleviates colic. If the digestive fire is weak, it is not able to digest the intake of *doṣa*-aggravating substances and medicine. Indeed, confusion regarding these can suddenly kill a sick person. But when the food has been digested, one should take medicine even if the abdomen feels stiff and heavy.  "

text: दोषशेषस्य पाकार्थमग्नेः सन्धुक्षणाय च। शान्तिरामविकाराणां भवति त्वपतर्पणात्॥
en_dmt: "For the digestion of the remaining faults, for the kindling of the fire, and for the pacification of diseases caused by Āma, there is alleviation.  "

text: त्रिविधं त्रिविधे दोषे तत्समीक्ष्य प्रयोजयेत्। तत्राल्पे लङ्घनं पथ्यं, मध्ये लङ्घनपाचनम्॥
en_dmt: "[The physician] should use these three types of buttermilk according to the doṣa, digestive fire, and strength. In a minor condition, fasting therapy (laṅghana) is beneficial, in a moderate condition, fasting therapy and digestion-promoting therapy (pācana) [are beneficial].  "

text: प्रभूते शोधनं, तद्धि मूलादुन्मूलयेन्मलान्। एवमन्यानपि व्याधीन् स्वनिदानविपर्ययात्॥
en_dmt: "Extensive purification, for that uproots impurities from the root. Likewise, other diseases [are cured] by reversing their own causes.  "

text: चिकित्सेदनुबन्धे तु सति हेतुविपर्ययम्। त्यक्त्वा यथायथं वैद्यो युञ्ज्याद्व्याधिविपर्ययम्॥
en_dmt: "But if the persistence [of the disease] remains, one should treat the reversal of the cause (hetu-viparyaya). Having abandoned each thing appropriately, the physician should apply the reversal of the disease (vyādhi-viparyaya).  "

text: तदर्थकारि वा, पक्वे दोषे त्विद्धे च पावके। हितमभ्यञ्जन-स्नेहपान-बस्त्यादि युक्तितः॥
en_dmt: "Or that which accomplishes the purpose, when the *doṣa* is ripe, and the fire is kindled. Beneficial is *abhyāñjana* (massage), intake of oil, *basti* (enema), etc., applied skillfully.  "

text: अजीर्णं च कफादामं तत्र शोफोऽक्षिगण्डयोः। सद्योभुक्त इवोद्गारः प्रसेकोत्क्लेशगौरवम्॥
en_dmt: "And indigestion, and phlegm from āma, then swelling on the eyes and cheeks; belching as if immediately after eating, salivation, affliction, and heaviness.  "

text: विष्टब्दमनिलाच्छूलविबन्धाध्मानसादकृत्। पित्ताद्विदग्धं तृण्मोहभ्रमाम्लोद्गारदाहवत्॥
en_dmt: "Due to *anila*, it causes constipation, colic, obstruction, distension, and exhaustion. Due to *pitta*, it is burning, causing thirst, delusion, dizziness, sour eructation, and a burning sensation.  "

text: लङ्घनं कार्यमामे तु, विष्टब्धे स्वेदनं भृशम्। विदग्धे वमनं, यद्वा यथावस्थं हितं भजेत्॥
en_dmt: "In cases of indigestion, fasting is appropriate; in cases of constipation, profuse sweating is beneficial. In cases of burning sensation, vomiting or whatever is beneficial according to the condition should be employed.  "

text: गरीयसो भवेल्लीनादामादेव विलम्बिका। कफवातानुबद्धाऽऽमलिङ्गा तत्समसाधना॥
en_dmt: "*Garīyaso bhavel līnād āmād eva vilambikā*.  *Kaphavātānubaddhā'maliṅgā tat-sama-sādhanā*.  Vilambikā arises from *āma* that is latent and serious. Its signs are connected with *kapha* and *vāta*, and its treatment is similar to that.  "

text: अश्रद्धा ह्रद्व्यथा शुद्धेऽप्युद्गारे रसशेषतः। शयीत किञ्चिदेवात्र सर्वश्चानाशितो दिवा॥ स्वप्यादजीर्णी, सञ्जातबुभुक्षोऽद्यान्मितं लघु। विबन्धोऽतिप्रवृत्तिर्वा ग्लानिर्मारुतमूढता॥
en_dmt: "Lack of faith, heart pain, even after a pure (or proper) belch, [and] residual taste [of food];  One should lie down a little here, and all day one should not eat.  One should sleep when there is indigestion; when hunger arises, one should eat moderately and lightly.  Constipation or excessive evacuation, or weakness, [or] derangement of *vāta*.  "

text: अजीर्णलिङ्गं सामान्यं विष्टम्भो गौरवं भ्रमः। न चातिमात्रमेवान्न,मामदोषाय केवलम्॥
en_dmt: "The general symptoms of indigestion are distension, heaviness, and dizziness. And not eating too much is the only way to avoid illness.  "

text: द्विष्ट-विष्टम्भि-दग्धाऽऽम-गुरु-रुक्ष-हिमाऽऽशुचि। विदाहि शुष्कमत्यम्बुप्लुतं चान्नं च जीर्यति॥ उपतप्तेन भुक्तं च शोकक्रोधक्षुदादिभिः। मिश्रं पथ्यमपथ्यं च भुक्तं समशनं मतम्॥
en_dmt: "Food that is disliked, causes flatulence, is burnt, undigested, heavy, rough, cold, impure, causes a burning sensation, is dry, excessively watery, or mixed does not digest.  Food that is eaten when afflicted by grief, anger, hunger, etc., or that is a mixture of wholesome and unwholesome things, is considered *samaśana* (unwholesome food).  "

text: विद्याद् 'अध्यशनं' भूयो भुक्तस्योपरि भोजनम्। अकाले बहु चाल्पं वा भुक्तं तु विषमाशनम्॥ त्रीण्यप्येतानि मृत्युं वा घोरान् व्याधीन्_ सृजन्ति वा। काले सात्म्यं शुचि हितं स्निग्धोष्मं लघु तन्मनाः॥
en_dmt: "One should know that *adhyashana* is eating again after having eaten. *Vishamaashana* is eating at the wrong time, too much, or too little. These three also cause death or create terrible diseases. At the right time, [food should be] wholesome, pure, beneficial, unctuous, warm, light, and agreeable.  "

text: षड्रसं मधुरप्रायं नातिद्रुतविलम्बितम्। स्नातः क्षुद्वान् विविक्तस्थो धौतपादकराननः॥ तर्पयित्वा पितृन् देवानतिथीन् बालकान् गुरून्। प्रत्यवेक्ष्य तिरश्चोऽपि प्रतिपन्नपरिग्रहान्॥ समीक्ष्य सम्यगात्मानमनिन्दन्नब्रुवन् द्रवम्। इष्टमिष्टैः सहाश्नीयाच्छुचि भक्तजनाऽऽहृतम्॥
en_dmt: "Possessing the six tastes, mostly sweet, neither too fast nor too slow; Having bathed, hungry, staying in a secluded place, having washed feet, hands, and face; Having satisfied the ancestors, the gods, the guests, the children, and the teachers; Having considered even the animals who are dependent on one's care; Having properly examined oneself, without criticizing, without speaking hastily; One should eat what is desired with those who are dear, pure food brought by devotees.  "

text: भोजनं तृणकेशादि-जुष्टमुष्णीकृतं पुनः। शकाऽवरान्नभूयिष्ठमत्युष्णलवणं त्यजेत्॥
en_dmt: "One should avoid food infested with grass and hair, reheated, mostly consisting of Śaka and *avara* food, and excessively hot and salty.  "

text: किलाटदधिकूर्चीका-क्षारशुक्ताऽऽममूलकम्। कृशशुष्कवराहावि-गोमत्स्यमहिषामिषम्॥ माषनिष्पावशालूक-बिसपिष्टविरूढकम्। शुष्कशाकानि यवकान् फाणितं च न शीलयेत्॥
en_dmt: "One should not regularly eat coagulated milk, thick sour curds, alkaline substances, śukta, unripe radish, the meat of lean and dry boar, cow, fish, or buffalo, māṣa beans, niṣpāva beans, śālūka, bisa, flour, sprouts, dried vegetables, barley, or treacle.  "

text: शीलयेच्छालिगोधूम-यवषष्टिकजाङ्गलम्। पथ्यामलकमृद्वीकापटोलीमुद्गशर्कराः॥ घृतदिव्योदकक्षीर-क्षौद्रदाडिमसैन्धवम्। त्रिफलां मधुसर्पिर्भ्यां निशि नेत्रबलाय च॥
en_dmt: "One should cultivate (a diet of) rice, wheat, barley, ṣaṣṭika rice, and meat of animals from arid lands, as well as pathyā, āmalaka, grapes, patolī, mung beans, and sugar.  (One should also cultivate a diet of) ghee, divyodaka water, milk, honey, pomegranates, and rock salt.  And at night, for the strength of the eyes, triphalā with honey and ghee.  "

text: स्वास्थ्यानुवृत्तिकृद्यच्च रोगोच्छेदकरं च तत्। बिसेक्षुमोचचोचाऽऽम्र-मोदकोत्कारिकादिकम्॥
en_dmt: "That which maintains health and eradicates disease, [such as] lotus stems, sugarcane, banana, Cocha, mango, sweetmeats, Utkarika, etc.  "

text: अद्याद्द्रव्यं गुरु स्निग्धं स्वादु मन्दं स्थिरं पुरः। विपरीतमतश्चान्ते मध्येऽम्ललवणोत्कटम्॥ अन्नेन कुक्षेर्द्वावंशौ पानेनैकं प्रपूरयेत्। आश्रयं पवनादीनां चतुर्थमवशेषयेत्॥
en_dmt: "One should first eat substances that are heavy (guru), unctuous (snigdha), sweet (svādu), slow [to digest] (manda), and stable (sthira). Afterwards, [one should eat] the opposite of that, and in the middle, [food that is] intensely sour (amla) and salty (lavana). One should fill two parts of the stomach with food (annena), and one part with drink (pānena). One should leave one-fourth empty as a place for wind and the like (vāyu).  "

text: अनुपानं हिमं वारि यवगोधूमयोर्हितम्।। दध्नि मध्ये विषे क्षौद्रे, कोष्णं पिष्टमयेषु तु॥
en_dmt: "The vehicle (anupāna) is cold water, which is beneficial with barley and wheat.  In yogurt, [it is beneficial] in the middle [of a meal]; in poison, honey; and lukewarm [water is beneficial] with flour-based foods.  "

text: शाकमुद्गादिविकृतौ मस्तुतक्राम्लकाञ्जिकम्। सुरा कृशानां पुष्ट्यर्थं, स्थूलानां तु मधूदकम्॥ शोषे मांसरसो, मद्यं मांसे स्वल्पे च पावके। व्याध्यौषदाध्वभाष्यस्री-लङ्घनातपकर्मभिः॥ क्षीणे वृद्धे च बाले च पयः पथ्यं यथाऽमृतम्। विपरीतं यदन्नस्य गुणैः स्यादविरोधि च॥
en_dmt: "Buttermilk, sour gruel, and kāñjika (fermented rice water) are suitable when [vegetables like] *mūga* beans, etc., are processed.  Wine (*surā*) is for nourishing the emaciated, while honey-water (*madhūdaka*) is for the corpulent.  Meat soup is [good] in wasting diseases, and wine when meat is scarce and the digestive fire is weak.  In emaciation due to disease, medicine, travel, speech, women, fasting, exposure to the sun, and physical labor,  milk is as beneficial as ambrosia for the debilitated, the elderly, and children.  [One should take food] that is opposite to the qualities of the food [one has already taken] and is also non-antagonistic.  "

text: अनुपानं समासेन, सर्वदा तत्प्रशस्यते। अनुपानं करोत्यूर्जां तृप्तिं व्याप्तिं दृढाङ्गताम्॥

text: मलानामतिसूक्ष्माणां दुर्लक्ष्यं लक्षयेत् क्षयम्। स्वमलायनसंशोष-तोदशून्यत्वलाघवैः॥
en_dmt: "One should observe the destruction of impurities that are extremely subtle and difficult to perceive, through the drying up of one's own impurities, the absence of pricking pain, and lightness.  "

text: दोषादीनां यथास्वं च विद्याद् वृद्धिक्षयौ भिषक्। क्षयेण विपरीतानां गुणानां वर्धनेन च॥ वृद्धिं मलानां सङ्गाच्च क्षयं चाति विसर्गतः। मलोचितत्वाद् देहस्य क्षयो वृद्धेस्तु पीडनः॥
en_dmt: "The physician should understand the increase and decrease of the *doṣas*, etc., each according to its own nature. And by increasing the qualities opposite to those that have decreased.  Increase [of *doṣas*] is from accumulation of impurities, and decrease is from excessive elimination. Because the body is suited to impurities, decrease [of them] is weakening, while increase is tormenting.  "

text: तत्रास्थनि स्थितो वायुः, पित्तं तु स्वेदरक्तयोः। श्लेष्मा शेषेषु , तेनैषामाश्रयाश्रयिणां मिथः॥ यदेकस्य तदन्यस्य वर्धनक्षपणौषधम्। अस्थिमारुतयोर्नैवं, प्रायो वृद्धिर्हि तर्पणात्॥ श्लेष्मणाऽनुगत तस्मात् सङ्क्षयस्तद्विपर्ययात्। वायुनाऽनुगतोऽस्माच्च वृद्धिक्षयसमुद्भवान्॥ विकारान् साधयेच्छीघ्रं क्रमाल्लङ्घनबृंहणैः। वायोरन्यत्र, तज्जांस्तु तैरेवोत्क्रमयोजितैः॥
en_dmt: "There, *vāyu* abides in the bones, while *pitta* [abides] in sweat and blood. *Śleṣma* [abides] in the remaining [tissues]. Therefore, these are mutually the support and the supported. That which is for one is for the other a medicine for increase and decrease.  It is not like that for bone and *māruta*; generally, increase is indeed from nourishment. Therefore, when attended by *śleṣma*, there is decrease, and the opposite from that. When attended by *vāyu*, from this [arise] increase, decrease, and origination.  One should quickly remedy the disorders in sequence with depletion and nourishment, except for *vāyu*; but those born from it, with those same [treatments] applied in reverse order.  "

text: विशेषाद्रक्तवृद्ध्युत्थान् रक्तस्रुतिचिविरेचनैः। मांसवृद्धिभवान् रोगान् शस्त्रक्षाराग्निकर्मभिः॥ स्थौल्यकार्श्योपचारेण मेदोजानस्थिसङ्क्षयात्। जातान् क्षीरघृतैस्तिक्तसंयुतैर्बस्तिभिस्तथा॥ विड्_वृद्धिजानतीसार-क्रियया, विट्_क्षयोद्भवान्। मेषाजमद्यकुल्माष-यवमाषद्वयादिभिः॥ मूत्रवृद्धिक्षयोत्थांश्च मेहकृच्छ्रचिकित्सया। व्यायामाभ्यञ्जनस्वेद-मद्यैः स्वेदक्षयोद्भवान्॥
en_dmt: "Especially those arising from an increase in blood [treated] by bloodletting and purgatives; diseases arising from an increase in muscle [treated] by surgical excision, alkalis, and fire cauterization; those arising from obesity and emaciation [treated] by nourishing therapies, those born from the depletion of *medas* and bone [treated] with enemas mixed with milk, ghee, and bitter substances; those arising from an increase in feces [treated] by therapies for diarrhea, those born from the depletion of feces [treated] with ram, goat, alcohol, *kulmāṣa*, barley, *māṣa*, *dvaya*, etc.; and those arising from an increase or depletion of urine [treated] by therapies for urinary disorders and dysuria; those arising from the depletion of sweat [treated] with exercise, massage, sudation, and alcohol.  "

text: स्वस्थानस्थस्य कायाग्नेरंशा धातुषु संश्रिताः। तेषां सादातिदीप्तिभ्यां धातुवृद्धिक्षयोद्भवः॥ पूर्वो धातुः परं कुर्याद् वृद्धः क्षीणश्च तद्विधम्। दोषा दुष्टा रसैर्धातून् दूषयन्त्युभये मलान्॥
en_dmt: "The portions of the bodily fire residing in their own places in the tissues (dhātu)s; through their depletion or excess, the increase and decrease of the tissues (dhātu)s occur.  The first tissue (dhātu) benefits the subsequent one; when increased or decreased, it acts similarly. When vitiated, the humors (doṣa)s, along with the tastes (rasa)s, corrupt the tissues (dhātu)s, and both [corrupt] the waste products (mala)s.  "

text: अधो द्वे, सप्त शिरसि, खानि स्वेदवहानि च। मला मलायनानि स्युर्यथास्वं तेष्वतो गदाः॥
en_dmt: "Two [external] orifices below, seven orifices in the head, and channels for sweat.  Waste products are the sites of waste products; therefore, diseases arise in their respective locations.  "

text: ओजस्तु तेजो धातूनां शुक्रान्तानां परं स्मृतम्। हृदयस्थमपि व्यापि देहस्थितिनिबन्धनम्॥ स्निग्धं सोमात्मकं शुद्धमीषल्लोहितपीतकम्। यन्नाशे नियतं नाशो यस्मिंस्तिष्ठति तिष्ठति॥ निष्पद्यन्ते यतो भावा विविधा देहसंश्रयाः। ओजः क्षीयेत कोपक्षुद्ध्यान-शोक-श्रमादिभिः॥
en_dmt: "Ojas is remembered as the supreme essence of the *dhātus*, ending with semen. Although located in the heart, it pervades [the body] and is the basis for the body's stability. [It is] unctuous, of a lunar nature (*somātmaka*), pure, and slightly reddish-yellow. When it is destroyed, destruction is certain; when it remains, [life] remains. (यन्-नाशे नियतं नाशो यस्मिंस् तिष्ठति तिष्ठति) From it arise the various states that depend on the body. Ojas diminishes due to anger, hunger, contemplation, sorrow, exertion, and so on.  "

text: बिभेति दुर्बलोऽभीक्ष्णं ध्यायति व्यथितेन्द्रियः। विच्छायो दुर्मना रूक्षो भवेत्क्षामश्च तत्क्षये॥ जीवनीयौषधक्षीर-रसाद्यास्तत्र भेषजम्। ओजोवृद्धौ हि देहस्य तुष्टिपुष्टिबलोदयः॥
en_dmt: "The weak man is constantly afraid, his senses are afflicted, he broods. He becomes lusterless, sad, rough, and emaciated at its decline.  Life-giving medicine, milk, juice, and so on are the remedies for that. For the increase of *ojas* in the body [there is] satisfaction, nourishment, strength, and vigor.  "

text: यदन्नं द्वेष्टि यदपि प्रार्थयेताविरोधि तु। तत्तत्त्यजन् समश्नंश्च तौ तौ वृद्धिक्षयौ जयेत्॥
en_dmt: "He should conquer those increases and decreases by abandoning whatever food he hates and whatever, though not harmful, he desires, and by eating moderately.  "

text: कुर्वते हि रुचिं दोषा विपरीतसमानयोः। वृद्धाः क्षीणाश्च भूयिष्ठं लक्षयन्त्यबुधास्तु न॥
en_dmt: "Indeed, the *doṣas* (faults, blemishes, or imbalances) create a liking for things that are opposite and similar. The old and the weak mostly perceive this, but the unwise do not.  "

text: यथाबलं यथास्वं च दोषा वृद्धा वितन्वते। रूपाणि,जहति क्षीणाः, समाः स्वं कर्म कुर्वते॥
en_dmt: "The *doṣas*, when increased, spread according to their strength (*yathābalam*) and their own nature (*yathāsvam*); when diminished, they abandon their forms; when balanced, they perform their own function (*svam karma kurvate*).  "

text: य एव देहस्य समा विवृद्ध्यै त एव दोषा विषमा वधाय। यस्मादतस्तेहितचर्ययैव,क्षयाद्विवृद्धेरिव रक्षणीयाः॥
en_dmt: "Whatever is balanced for the body's growth, those very things, if unbalanced, are for its destruction.  Therefore, they should be protected by beneficial practices, just as one protects against decline and excessive growth.  "

text: इति श्रीवैद्यपतिसिंहगुप्तसूनश्रीमद्वाग्भटविरचिता- यामष्टाङ्गहृदयसंहितायां सूत्रस्थाने दोषादि- विज्ञानीयो नामैकादशोऽध्यायः॥

text: 02द्वादशोध्यायः अथातो दोषभेदीयाध्यायं व्याख्यास्यामः। इति ह स्माहुरात्रेयादयो महर्षयः।

text: पक्वाशय-कटी-सक्थि-श्रोत्राऽस्थिस्पर्शनेन्द्रियम्। स्थानं वातस्य, तत्रापि पक्वाधानं विशेषतः॥
en_dmt: "The digestive organ, hip, thigh, ear, bone, and sense of touch. It is the place of *vāta* (wind), and especially the place of digestion (*pakvādhāna*).  "

text: नाभिरामाशयः स्वेदो लसीका रुधिरं रसः। दृक् स्पर्शनं च पित्तस्य, नाभिरत्र विशेषतः॥
en_dmt: "The navel, stomach, sweat, lymph, blood, and sap (rasa); the eye and skin are sites of *pitta*, but the navel is especially so.  "

text: उरः कण्ठशिरः क्लेम-पर्वाण्यामाशयो रसः। मेदो घ्राणं च जिह्वा च कफस्य, सुतरामुरः॥

en_dmt: "The *vāyu* [wind, vital air] is [divided into] five, [distinguished] by *prāṇa* [etc.]. Of these five, *prāṇa* here resides in the head. [It] generally moves in the chest and throat; [it] holds [or controls] the intellect, senses, mind, and heart.  "

text: ष्ठीवनक्षवथूद्गार-निःश्वासान्नप्रवेशकृत्। उरः स्थानमुदानस्य नासानाभिगलांश्चरेत्॥
en_dmt: "One who makes spitting, sneezing, belching, exhaling, and the entering of food [happen]. The location of *udāna* is the chest; it moves through the nose, navel, and throat.  "

text: वाक्प्रवृत्तिप्रयत्नोर्जा-बलवर्णस्मृतिक्रियः। व्यानो हृदि स्थितः कृत्स्नदेहचारी महाजवः॥
en_dmt: "[It causes] the utterance of syllables, exertion, purification, strength, complexion, memory [and] action. The *vyāna*-[wind] dwells in the heart, moves throughout the entire body, [and is] very swift.  "

text: गत्यपक्षेपणोत्क्षेप-निमेषोन्मेषणादिकाः। प्रायः सर्वाः क्रियास्तस्मिन् प्रतिबद्धाः शरीरिणाम्॥
en_dmt: "Walking, throwing down, throwing up, closing and opening the eyes, and so forth; nearly all the actions of embodied beings are dependent on that.  "

text: समानोऽग्निसमीपस्थः कोष्ठे चरति सर्वतः। अन्नं गृह्णाति पचति विवेचयति मुञ्चति॥
en_dmt: "The *samāna* dwells near the digestive fire, moves throughout the stomach, takes in food, digests it, separates [nutrients and waste], and eliminates [the waste].  "

text: अपानोऽपानगः श्रोणि-बस्तिमेढ्रोरुगोचरः। शुक्रार्तवशकृन्मूत्र-गर्भनिष्क्रमणक्रियः॥
en_dmt: "The *apāna*-[wind] moves downwards, its sphere of activity being the hips, bladder, penis, and thighs. It governs the expulsion of semen, menstrual blood, feces, urine, and the fetus.  "

text: पित्तं पञ्चात्मकं तत्र पक्वामाशयमध्यगम्। पञ्चभूतात्मकत्वेऽपि यत्तैजसगुणोदयात्॥
en_dmt: "Bile is fivefold in nature, and is situated in the middle of the digestive and undigestive receptacles. Although it is of the nature of the five elements, it arises from an excess of the quality of fire (taijasaguṇa).  "

text: त्यक्तद्रवत्वं पाकादि-कर्मणाऽनलशब्दितम्। पचत्यन्नं विभजते सारकिट्टौ पृथक् तथा॥ तत्रस्थमेव पित्तानां शेषाणामप्यनुग्रहम्। करोति बलदानेन पाचकं नाम तत्समृतम्॥
en_dmt: "[Fire], called *anala*, has relinquished its fluidity through processes like cooking.  It digests food and separates the essence (*sāra*) and waste (*kiṭṭa*) distinctly.  Remaining there, it also supports the other *pittas*  by giving strength; it is known as *pācaka* (digestive fire).  "

text: आमाशयाश्रयं पित्तं रञ्जकं रसरञ्जनात्। बुद्धिमेधाभिमानाद्यैरभिप्रेतार्थसाधनात्॥
en_dmt: "*Pitta*, residing in the stomach, is *rañjaka* because it colors the *rasa*. Intellect (buddhi) [is that] by which the desired object is accomplished, [such as] intelligence, memory, and pride.  "

text: साधकं हृद्गतं पित्तं रूपालोचनतः स्मृतम्। दृक्स्थमालोचकं	त्वक्स्थं भ्राजकं भ्राजनात्त्वचः॥
en_dmt: "*Sādhaka* *pitta* located in the heart is known from the observation of form (rūpa). That which is located in the eye is *ālocaka*; that which is located in the skin is *bhrājaka*, from the shining of the skin.  "

text: श्लेष्मा तु पञ्चधा उरः स्थः स त्रिकस्य स्ववीर्यतः। हृदयस्यान्नवीर्याच्च तत्स्थ एवाम्बुकर्मणा॥
en_dmt: "The phlegm, however, is fivefold. Situated in the chest, it [supports] the three vital principles (trika) through its own power. From the power of food, it is situated in the heart and performs the function of water.  "

text: कफधाम्नां च शेषाणां यत्करोत्यवलम्बनम्। अतोऽवलम्बकः श्लेष्मा	यस्त्वामाशयसंस्थितः॥
en_dmt: "That which provides support to the remaining Kapha sites; therefore, the Śleṣma which is situated in the stomach is called Avalambaka.  "

text: क्लेदकः सोऽन्नसङ्घात-क्लेदनात् रसबोधनात्। बोधको रसनास्थायी शिरः संश्तोऽक्षतर्पणात्।17।।
en_dmt: "*kledakaḥ* [is so called] because it moistens the mass of food and causes a sensation of taste.  *bodhakaḥ* [is so called] because it abides in the tongue, alleviates the head, and satisfies the eyes.  "

text: तर्पकः	सन्धिसंश्लेषाच्छ्लेषकः सन्धिषु स्थितिः। इति प्रायेण दोषाणां स्थानान्यविकृतात्मनाम्॥
en_dmt: "*Tarpaka*: Because of the adhesion and cohesion of joints, *śleṣaka* is the maintenance of the joints.  Thus, generally, these are the locations of the faults of those whose nature is not distorted.  "

text: व्यापिनामपि जानीयात्कर्माणि च पृथक्पृथक्। उष्णेन युक्ता रूक्षाद्या वायोः कुर्वन्ति सञ्चयम्॥
en_dmt: "Even though pervasive, one should know their actions separately. Dry foods, etc., combined with heat, cause an accumulation of vāyu.  "

text: शीतेन कोपमुष्मेन शमं स्निग्धादयो गुणाः। शीतेन युक्तास्तीक्ष्णाद्याश्चयं पित्तस्य कुर्वते॥
en_dmt: "Coldness aggravates [it], heat alleviates [it]; unctuousness and other qualities [pacify it]. Qualities such as sharpness, combined with coldness, increase pitta.  "

text: उष्णेन कोपं, मन्दाद्याः शमं शीतोपसंहिताः। शीतेन युक्ताः स्निग्धाद्याः कुर्वते श्लेष्मणश्चयम्॥
en_dmt: "Heat provokes anger, while mild [substances] and those combined with cooling [properties] alleviate it. Those combined with cold and unctuous [substances] cause an accumulation of *śleṣma* (phlegm).  "

text: उष्णेन कोपं, तेनैव गुणा रूक्षादयः शमम्। चयो वृद्धिः स्वधाम्न्येव प्रद्वेषो वृद्धिहेतुषु॥
en_dmt: "Anger is [pacified] by heat (_uṣṇena_), and by that same [heat], qualities like roughness (_rūkṣa_) are calmed.  Accumulation (_cayaḥ_) [leads to] increase in one's own abode (_svadhāmni eva_), and aversion (_pradveṣaḥ_) [leads to] increase in the causes of increase.  "

text: विपरीतगुणेच्छा च कोपस्तून्मार्गगामिता। लिङ्गानां दर्शनं स्वेषामस्वास्थ्यं रोगसम्भवः॥
en_dmt: "And desire for opposite qualities, anger, and straying from the path, the appearance of signs of one's own illness, and the arising of disease.  "

text: स्वस्थानस्थस्य समता विकाराऽसम्भवः शमः। चय-प्रकोप-प्रशमा वायोर्ग्रीष्मादिषु त्रिषु॥
en_dmt: "Equanimity is the state of remaining in one's own place, absence of change is peace. The accumulation, aggravation, and pacification of *vāyu* [wind] occur in the three seasons beginning with summer.  "

text: वर्षादिषु तु पित्तस्य, श्लेष्मणः शिशिरादिषु। चीयते लघुरूक्षाभिरोषधीभिः समीरणः॥
en_dmt: "But in the rainy season etc., pitta [accumulates], and in the cold season etc., phlegm [accumulates]. Vāta [accumulates] from light and dry herbs.  "

text: तद्विधस्तद्विधे देहे कालस्यौष्ण्येन्न कुप्यति। अद्भिरम्लविपाकाभिरोषधीभिश्च तादृशम्॥ पित्तं याति चयं कोपं न तु कालस्य शैत्यतः। चीयते स्निग्धशीताभिरुदकौषधिभिः कफः॥ तुल्येऽपि काले देहे च स्कन्नत्वान्न प्रकुप्यति। इति कालस्वभावोऽयम् आहारादिवशात्पुनः॥
en_dmt: "When the body is of that nature, the heat of time does not aggravate [the *pitta*]. But *pitta* is increased by sour and pungent liquids and herbs.  *Pitta* undergoes accumulation and aggravation, but not due to the coldness of time. *Kapha* is accumulated by oily, cold liquids and herbs.  Even when the time is the same, it does not become aggravated in the body due to coagulation. Thus, this is the nature of time, but again, due to the influence of diet and so forth...  "

text: चयादीन् यान्ति सद्योऽपि दोषाः कालेऽपि वा न तु। व्याप्नोति सहसा देहमापादतलमस्तकम्॥
en_dmt: "Defects such as *caya* arise quickly or in time, but not so. It quickly pervades the body from the soles of the feet to the crown of the head.  "

text: निवर्तते तु कुपितो मलोऽल्पाल्पं जलौघवत्। नानारूपैरसङ्ख्येयैर्विकारैः कुपिता मलाः॥
en_dmt: "However, the aggravated *mala* (waste product) subsides little by little, like a stream of water. The aggravated *malas* (waste products), with countless transformations of various kinds,  "

text: तापयन्ति तनुं तस्मात्तद्धेत्वाकृतिसाधनम्। शक्यं नैकैकशो वक्तुमतः सामान्यमुच्यते॥
en_dmt: "Because they heat the body, that [fire] is the means for the form that is the cause of that [heating]. It is not possible to state each one individually; therefore, a general statement is made. (शक्यं नैकैक-शो वक्तुम् अतः सामान्यम् उच्यते)  "

text: दोषा एव हि सर्वेषां रोगाणामेककारणम्। यथा पक्षी परिपतन् सर्वतः सर्वमप्यहः॥ छायामत्येति नात्मीयां यथा वा कृत्स्नमप्यदः। विकारजातं विविधं त्रीन् गुणान्नातिवर्तते॥ तथा स्वधातुवैषम्य-निमित्तमपि सर्वदा। विकारजातं त्रीन्दोषान् तेषां कोपे तु कारणम्॥
en_dmt: "Indeed, the doṣas alone are the single cause of all diseases.  Just as a bird flying around everywhere for the entire day,  Goes beyond its own shadow, or as all of this [world does].  The various kinds of manifested effects do not transcend the three *guṇas*.  Similarly, always, the cause of all manifested effects is the disturbance of one's own *dhātu*s. The cause of their aggravation is the three *doṣas*.  "

text: अर्थैरसात्म्यैः संयोगः कालः कर्म च दुष्कृतम्। हीनातिमिथ्यायोगेन भिद्यते तत्पुनस्रिधा॥
en_dmt: "The connection with objects that are unwholesome, time, and bad actions, when connected deficiently, excessively, or wrongly, that is again divided threefold.  "

text: हीनोऽर्थेनेन्द्रयस्याल्पः संयोगः स्वेन नैव वा। अतियोगोऽतिसंसर्गः, सूक्ष्मभासुरभैरवम्॥ अत्यासन्नातिदूरस्थं विप्रियं विकृतादि च। यदक्ष्णा वीक्ष्चते रूपं मिथ्यायोगः स दारुणः॥ एवमत्युच्चपूत्यादीनिन्दियार्थान् यथायथम्। विद्यात् 	कालस्तु शीतोष्ण-वर्षाभेदात् त्रिधा मतः॥
en_dmt: "Deficient contact of the sense faculty with its own object is slight or even nonexistent.  Excessive contact is excessive association, [such as] subtle, radiant, and terrible [objects].  That form which is seen by the eye, being very near, very far, unpleasant, deformed, etc., is false contact, and it is terrible.  Likewise, one should understand the objects of the senses, such as very high, foul-smelling, etc., as appropriate.  Time, however, is considered threefold, due to the distinctions of cold, heat, and rain.  "

text: स हीनो हीनशीतादिरतियोगोऽतिलक्षणः। मिथ्यायोगस्तु निर्दिष्टो विपरीतस्वलक्षणः॥
en_dmt: "He is inferior, with excessive indulgence in inferior cold, etc., and has excessive characteristics. Improper therapy (*mithyā-yogaḥ*) is taught as having characteristics opposite to its own (*viparīta-sva-lakṣaṇaḥ*).  "

text: काय-वाक्_चित्तभेदन कर्मापि विभजेत् त्रिधा। कायादिकर्मणो हीना प्रवृत्तिर्हीनसंज्ञकः॥ अतियोगोऽतिवृत्तिस्तु, वेगोदीरणधारणम्। विषमाङ्गक्रियारम्भ-पतनस्खलनादिकम्॥ भाषणं सामिभुक्तस्य रागद्वेषभयादि च। कर्म प्राणातिपातादि दशधा यच्च निन्दितम्॥ मिथ्यायोगः समस्तोऽसाविह वाऽमुत्र वा कृतम्। निदानमेतद्दोषाणां, कुपितास्तेन नैकधा॥
en_dmt: "By the distinction of body, speech, and mind (kāya-vāk-citta-bhedena), action (karma) is also divided in three ways. (काय-वाक्-चित्त-भेदेन कर्मापि विभजेत् त्रि-धा) A base activity (hīna-pravṛtti) of actions such as those of the body is called \"base\" (hīna-saṃjñaka). Excessive application is exceeding (atiyogaḥ-ativṛttistu), and speed is the impelling and maintaining [of that application]. Beginning uneven bodily actions, falling, stumbling, and so on, Speaking while still eating, attraction (rāga), aversion (dveṣa), fear (bhaya), and so on, and action (karma) such as killing (prāṇātipāta), which is condemned in ten ways, All false application (mithyāyogaḥ) is done either here or there. This is the cause of faults; by that, they are angered in various ways.  "

text: कुर्वन्ति विविदान् व्याधीन् शाखाकोष्ठास्थिसन्धिषु शाखा रक्तादयस्त्वक् च बाह्यरोगायनं हि तत्॥
en_dmt: "They cause various diseases in the limbs, abdomen, bones, and joints. The *śākhā*s are blood, etc., and the skin is the external abode of diseases.  "

text: तदाश्रया मष-व्यङ्ग-गण्डा-लज्यर्बुदादयः। बहिर्भागाश्च दुर्नाम-गुल्म-शोफादयो गदाः॥
en_dmt: "Then, diseases such as *maṣa*, *vyaṅga*, *gaṇḍa*, *alajī*, *arbuda*, etc., which are dependent on that [blood], and external diseases such as *durnāma*, *gulma*, *śopha*, etc., [are caused].  "

text: अन्तःकोष्ठो महास्रोत आमपक्वाशयाश्रयः। तत्सथानाश्च्छर्द्यतीसारकासश्वासोदरज्वराः॥ अन्तर्भागं च शोफार्शोगुल्मवीसर्पविद्रधिः। शिरोहृदयवस्त्यादि-मर्माण्यस्थ्नां च सन्धयः॥
en_dmt: "The inner abdomen is the seat of the great channel, the receptacle of digested and undigested food.  There are also the locations for vomiting, diarrhea, cough, asthma, abdominal disease, and fever.  The inner parts [contain] swelling, hemorrhoids, tumors, erysipelas, and abscesses.  The vital spots, such as the head, heart, bladder, etc., and the joints of the bones [are also there].  "

text: तन्निबद्धाः सिरास्नायु-कण्डराद्याश्च मध्यमः। रोगमार्गे स्थितास्तत्र यक्ष्मपक्षवधार्दिताः॥ मूर्धादिरोगाः सन्ध्यस्थि-त्रिकशूलग्रहादयः। स्रंसव्यासव्यधस्वाप-सादरुक्तोदभेदनम्॥
en_dmt: "The *sirā*s (vessels), *snāyu*s (ligaments), *kaṇḍarā*s (tendons), and so forth, which are connected to that (tan), are medium (madhyamaḥ). Situated there in the course of the disease, they are afflicted by consumption, paralysis, and *ardita* (facial paralysis). Diseases beginning in the head, those located in the joints and bones, *trikaśūla* (pain in the sacral region), seizures, and so on, as well as displacement, distension, piercing, numbness, *sādaru*k (pain with throbbing), pricking, and cutting.  "

text: सङ्गाऽङ्गभङ्ग-सङ्कोच-वर्त-हर्षण-तर्षणम्। कम्प-पारुष्य-सौषिर्य-शोष-स्पन्दन-वेष्टनम्॥ स्तम्भः कषायरसता वर्णः श्यावोऽरुणोऽपि वा। कर्माणि वायोः	पित्तस्य दाहरागोष्मपाकिताः॥
en_dmt: "Association, breaking of limbs, contraction, whirling, erection, thirst, trembling, roughness, hollowness, dryness, throbbing, and wrapping; rigidity; astringent taste; a complexion that is either dark or reddish; these are the actions of *vāyu*. Burning, color, heat, and digestion are the actions of *pitta*.  "

text: स्वेदः कत्लेदः स्रुतिः कोथः सदनं मूर्च्छनं मदः। कटुकाम्लौ रसौ वर्णः पाण्डुरारुणवर्जितः॥
en_dmt: "Sweat, katleda, flow, putrefaction, exhaustion, fainting, intoxication; the tastes are pungent and sour; the color is other than pale or reddish.  "

text: श्लष्मणः स्नेहकाठिन्य-  कण्डूशीतत्वगौरवम्। बन्धोपलेपस्तौमित्य-शोफापक्त्यतिनिद्रताः॥ वर्णः श्वेतो रसौ स्वादुलवणो चिरकारिता। इत्यशेषाऽऽमय-व्यापि यदुक्तं दोषलक्षणम्॥
en_dmt: "Sliminess, oleation, hardness, itching, coldness, heaviness, binding, coating, a feeling of being wrapped up, swelling, indigestion, and excessive sleep; a white complexion and a sweet-salty taste, and acting for a long time—this is the complete description of the *doṣa* that pervades all diseases, as has been stated.  "

text: दर्शनाद्यैरवहितस्तत्सम्यगुपलक्षयेत्। व्याध्यवस्था-विभागज्ञः पश्यन्नार्तान् प्रतिक्षणम्॥
en_dmt: "The physician, who understands the divisions of the stages of disease, should carefully observe [upalakṣayet] those who are afflicted, constantly seeing [paśyan] through observation [darśanād] and so forth [yair].  "

text: अभ्यासात्प्राप्यते दृष्टिः कर्मसिद्धिप्रकाशिनी। रत्नादिसदसज्ज्ञानं न शास्त्रदेव जायते॥
en_dmt: "Through practice, vision is attained, which illuminates the accomplishment of actions.  Knowledge of good and bad, like jewels and so forth, does not arise merely from scripture.  "

text: दृष्टापचारजः कश्चित्कश्चित्पूर्वापराधजः। तत्सङ्कराद्भवत्यन्यो व्याधिरेवं त्रिधा स्मृतः॥
en_dmt: "One [disease] arises from an offense that is seen, another arises from a previous offense. Another disease arises from the combination of these. Thus, it is known as threefold.  "

text: यथानिदानं दोषोत्थः कर्मजो हेतुभिर्विना। महारम्भोऽल्पके हेतावातङ्को दोषकर्मजः॥
en_dmt: "Just as a disease arises from faults, [and] actions are born without causes, a great undertaking with a small cause [leads to] suffering born of faults and actions.  "

text: विपक्षशीलनात्पूर्वः कर्मजः कर्मसङ्क्षयात्। गच्छत्युभयजन्मा तु दोषकर्मक्षयात्क्षयम्॥
en_dmt: "Through cultivating the opposite [of afflictions], [arises] karma born prior [to this life], from the exhaustion of karma. The twice-born goes to destruction through the exhaustion of the doṣas and karma.  "

text: द्विधा स्वपरतन्त्रत्वाद्व्याधयोऽन्त्याः पुनर्द्विधा। पूर्वजाः पूर्वरूपाख्या,जाताः पश्चादुपद्रवाः॥
en_dmt: "Diseases are twofold because of being dependent on oneself and others; again, the final [diseases] are twofold.  The former are said to be of a previous nature; the latter are born as afflictions.  "

text: यथास्वजन्मोपशयाः स्वतन्त्राः स्पष्टलक्षणाः। विपरीतास्ततोऽन्ये तु विद्यादेव मलानपि॥
en_dmt: "As for one's own abode, just as they are, independent and with clear characteristics, and those others that are the opposite of them, one should know that they are also impurities.  "

text: तांल्लक्षयेदवहितो विकुर्वाणान् प्रतिज्वरम्। तेषां प्रधानप्रशमे प्रशमोऽशाम्यतस्तथा॥
en_dmt: "He should carefully observe them as they display symptoms of recurring fever. When the chief symptom subsides, there is relief, but when it does not subside, [there is no relief].  "

text: पश्चाच्चिकित्सेत्तूर्णं वा बलवन्तमुपद्रवम्। व्याधिक्लिष्टशरीरस्य पीडाकरतरो हि सः॥
en_dmt: "Afterwards, one should quickly treat a powerful complication, for that is more distressing to a body afflicted by disease.  "

text: विकारनामाऽकुशलो न जीह्नीयात् कदाचन। न हि सर्वविकाराणां नामतोऽस्ति ध्रुवा स्थितिः॥
en_dmt: "One should never be ashamed of [their] ignorance of the names of diseases. [It is because] a fixed nomenclature for all diseases is not possible.  "

text: स एव कुपतो दोषः समुत्थानविशेषतः। स्थानान्तराणि च प्राप्य विकारान् कुरुते बहून्॥ तस्माद्विकारप्रकृतीरधिष्ठानान्तराणि च। बुद्ध्वा हेतुविशेषांश्च शीघ्रं कुर्यादुपक्रमम्॥
en_dmt: "That same aggravated *doṣa*, depending on the specific etiology. Having reached other sites, it produces many diseases. Therefore, understanding the nature of the disease, the other sites, and the specific causes, one should quickly begin treatment.  "

text: दूष्यं देशं बलं कालमनलं प्रकृतिं वयः। सत्त्वं सात्म्यं तथाऽऽहारमवस्थाश्च पृथग्विधाः॥ सूक्ष्मसूक्ष्माः समीक्ष्यैषां दोषौषधनिरूपणे। यो वर्तते चिकित्सायां न स स्खलति जातुचित्॥
en_dmt: "[The physician should consider] what is to be vitiated, the region (deśa), the strength (bala), the time (kāla), the digestive fire (anala), the constitution (prakṛti), the age (vayas), the mental strength (sattva), the suitability (sātmya), as well as the diet (āhāra), and the various conditions (avasthāḥ) separately.  Having examined these in minute detail (sūkṣmasūkṣmāḥ samīkṣya), in the determination of imbalances (doṣa) and remedies (auṣadha), he who engages in treatment (cikitsāyāṃ) never errs (na sa skhalati jātu cit).  "

text: गुर्वल्पव्याधिसंस्थानं सत्त्वदेहबलाबलात्। दृश्यतेऽप्यन्यथाकारं तस्मिन्नवहितो भवेत्॥
en_dmt: "Due to the strength and weakness of the mind, body, and strength, the body may appear with qualities such as being heavy, light, diseased, or healthy. One should be attentive to that.  "

text: गुरुं लघुमिति व्यधिं कल्पयंस्तु भिषग्ब्रुवः। अल्पदोषाकलनया पथ्ये विप्रतिपद्यते॥
en_dmt: "The one who calls himself a physician, but [only] imagines a disease to be serious (gurum) or mild (laghum), due to a poor assessment of the minor (alpa) *doṣa*s, errs in prescribing the appropriate treatment (pathye).  "

text: ततोऽल्पमल्पवीर्यं वा गुरुव्याधौ प्रयोजितम्। उदीरयेत्तरां रोगान् संशोधनमयोगतः॥ शोधनं त्वतियोगेन विपरीतं विपर्यये। क्षिणुयान्न मलानेव केवलं वपुरस्यपि॥
en_dmt: "Then, [a medicine] of little or weakened potency, if applied in a serious disease, will greatly provoke the diseases, due to improper purification. But purification with excessive application will cause the opposite effect. It will not only eliminate the impurities, but will also destroy the body.  "

text: अतोऽभियुक्तः सततं सर्वमालोच्य सर्वथा। तथा युञ्जीत भैषज्यमारोग्याय यथा ध्रुवम्॥
en_dmt: "Therefore, constantly striving and thoroughly considering everything in every way, one should apply medicine for health, just as surely as...  "

text: वक्ष्यन्तेऽतः परं दोषा वृद्धिक्षयविभेदतः। पृथक् त्रीन् विद्धि संसर्गस्त्रिधा, तत्र तु तान्नव॥
en_dmt: "Therefore, faults will be described hereafter, with distinctions of increase and decrease. Know the three as distinct; the combination is threefold; but there, they are nine.  "

text: त्रीनेव समया वृद्ध्या, षडेकस्यातिशायने। त्रयोदश समस्तेषु षड्द्व्येकातिशयेन तु।।75।
en_dmt: "Three indeed are the times by increase, six by the excess of one. Thirteen in all, six by the excess of two and one. nan Seventy-five.  "

text: पित्तस्य सर्पिषः पानं स्वादुशीतैर्विरेचनम्। स्वादुतिक्तकषायाणि भोजनान्यौषधानि च॥ सुगन्धिशीतहृद्यानां गन्धानामुपसेवनम्। कण्ठेगुणानां हाराणां मणीनामुरसा धृतिः॥ कर्पूरचन्दनोशीरैरनुलेपः क्षणे क्षणे। प्रदोषश्चन्द्रमाः सौधं हारि गीतं हिमोऽनिलः॥ अयन्त्रणसुखं मित्रं पुत्रः सन्दिग्धमुग्धवाक्। छन्दानुवर्तिनो दाराः प्रियाः शीलविभूषिताः॥ शीताम्बुधारागर्भाणि गृहाण्युद्यानदीर्घिकाः। सुतीर्थविपुलस्वच्छसलिलाशयसैकते॥ साम्भोजजलतीरान्ते कायमाने द्रुमाकुले। सौम्या भावाः पयः सर्पिर्विरेकश्च विशेषतः॥
en_dmt: "Drinking clarified butter for pitta, and purgation with sweet and cooling [medicines]. Foods and medicines that are sweet, bitter, and astringent. Exposure to fragrant, cooling, and pleasing smells. Wearing necklaces of qualities and jewels on the chest. Anointing with camphor, sandalwood, and uśīra (*Vetiveria zizanioides*) every moment. Evening, moonlight, a mansion, delightful song, and cool breeze. A peaceful friend [brings] happiness, [and towards] a son, speak [with] delightful, affectionate words. Wives who act according to [one's] wishes, beloved and adorned with good character. Houses filled with streams of cool water and garden ponds. On the sandy banks of reservoirs with good fords, wide and clear water, On the banks of water with lotuses, crowded with trees, Pleasant emotions, milk, clarified butter, and especially purgation.  "

text: श्लेष्मणो विधिना युक्तं तीक्ष्णं वमनरेचनम्। अन्नं रूक्षाल्पतीक्ष्णोष्णं कटुतिक्तकषायकम्॥ दीर्घकालस्थितं मद्यं रतिप्रीतिः प्रजागरः। अनेकरूपो व्यायामश्चिन्ता रूक्षं विमर्दनम्॥ विशेषाद्वमनं यूषः क्षौद्रं मेदोघ्नमौषधम्। धूमोपवासगण्डूषा निःसुखत्वं सुखाय च॥
en_dmt: "A sharp emetic and purgative, combined appropriately, [is effective] against *śleṣma*. Food that is dry, small in quantity, sharp, and hot; pungent, bitter, and astringent. text: कफोद्रेके गदेऽनन्नं बलिनो रोगरोगिणोः। अन्नादौ विगुणेऽपाने, समाने मध्य इष्यते॥ व्यानेऽन्ते प्रातराशस्य, सायमाशस्य तूत्तरे। ग्रासग्रासान्तयो प्राणे प्रदुष्टे मातरिश्वनि॥ मुहुर्मुहुर्विषच्छर्दिहिध्मातृट्_श्वासकासिषु। योज्यं सभोज्यं भैषज्यं भोज्यैश्चित्रैररोचके॥ कम्पाक्षेपकहिध्मासु सामुद्गं लघुभोजिनाम्। ऊर्ध्वजत्रुविकारेषु स्वप्नकाले प्रशस्यते॥

When *prāṇa* is deranged between bites and at the end of bites, and when *mātariśvan* [is deranged],  medicine should be administered frequently with food in cases of poisoning, vomiting, hiccup, thirst, dyspnea, and cough, and with various foods in cases of anorexia. text: बृंहणो लङ्घनश्चेति तत्पर्यायावुदाहृतौ। बृंहणं यद्बृहत्त्वाय लङ्घनं लाघवाय यत्॥ देहस्य भवतः प्रायो भौमापमितरेच्च ते। स्नेहनं रूक्षणं कर्म स्वेदनं स्तम्भनं च यत्॥
en_dmt: "*Bṛṃhaṇa* and *laṅghana* are cited as synonyms for that. *Bṛṃhaṇa* is that which is for increasing bulk, and *laṅghana* is that which is for lightness. en_dmt: "If the speed is diminished, one should repeatedly induce vomiting with kaṇā, dhātrī, siddhārtha, lavaṇa, and water. If the urge to vomit does not arise...  "

text: प्रवृत्तिः सविबन्धा वा केवलस्यौषधस्य वा। अयोगस्तेन निष्ठीव-कण्डूकोठज्वरादयः॥
en_dmt: "Application [of treatment] may be with binding or with only medicine. Due to improper application, there are symptoms such as spitting, itching, urticaria, fever, etc.  "

text: निर्विबन्धं प्रवर्तन्ते कफपित्तानिलाः क्रमात्। सम्यग्योगे अतियोगे तु फेनचन्द्रकरक्तवत्॥
en_dmt: "*Kapha*, *pitta*, and *anila* move unimpeded in their order. But with proper application or excessive application, [they appear] like foam, the moon, and blood.  "

text: वमितं क्षामता दाहः कण्ठशोषस्तमो भ्रमः। घोरा वाय्वामया मृत्युर्जीवशोणितनिर्गमात्॥
en_dmt: "Vomiting, emaciation, burning sensation, dryness of the throat, darkness [of vision], and dizziness [occur]. Severe diseases of *vāyu* and death [occur] from the discharge of *jīva-śoṇita* (blood that sustains life).  "

text: सम्यग्योगेन वमितं क्षणमाश्वास्य पाययेत्। धूमत्रयस्यान्यतमं स्नेहाचारमथादिशेत्॥
en_dmt: "Having induced vomiting through proper application, one should comfort [the patient] for a moment and then give [him/her something] to drink. Then one should prescribe one of the three fumigations or oleation therapy.  "

text: ततः सायं प्रभाते वा क्षुद्वान् स्नातः सुखाम्बुना। भुञ्जानो रक्तशाल्यन्नं भजेत्पेयादिकं क्रमम्।।28।
en_dmt: "Then, in the evening or morning, when hungry, one should bathe with pleasant water. Eating red-rice and then consuming gruel and the like in sequence.  "

text: पेयां विलेपीमकृतं कृतं च यूषं रसं त्रीनुभयं तथैकम्। क्रमेण सेवेत नरोऽन्नकालान् प्रधानमध्याऽवरशुद्धिशुद्धः॥
en_dmt: "After the body is cleansed, a person should take peyā (thin gruel), vilepī (thick gruel), unseasoned and seasoned vegetable soup (yūṣa), and three, two, or one [of the above]. One should consume these in sequence during meal times, being purified of the best, middling, and worst impurities.  "

text: यथाऽणुरग्निस्तृणगोमयाद्यैः सन्धुक्ष्यमाणो भवति क्रमेण। महान् स्थिरः सर्वंपचस्तथैव शुद्धस्य पेयादिभिरन्तराग्निः॥
en_dmt: "As a small spark of fire (aṇuḥ agniḥ) is gradually kindled into a large and stable flame when supplied with dry grass, cow dung (tṛṇa-gomaya), etc.; similarly, the digestive fire (antarāgniḥ) of a purified person becomes strong and stable, capable of digesting all types of food, by the sequential administration of peyā etc.  "

text: जघन्यमध्यप्रवरे तु वेगाश्चत्वार इष्टा वमने षडष्टौ। दशैव ते द्वित्रिगुणा विरेका      प्रस्थस्तथा स्याद् द्विचतुर्गुणश्च॥
en_dmt: "In inferior, moderate, and superior types of emesis, four, six, and eight urges [of vomiting are desirable]. In purgation, these [numbers] are doubled or tripled [respectively] as regards the number of evacuations. The quantity [of the purgative] is similarly doubled, tripled, or quadrupled.  "

text: पित्तावसानं वमनं विरेका-दर्द्ध, कफान्तं च विरेकमाहुः। द्वित्रान् सविट्कानपनीत वेगान् मेयं विरेके, वमने तु पीतम्॥
en_dmt: "Vamana is complete when pitta has been eliminated; virecana, when kapha has been eliminated, and [the volume of evacuations is] half [that of vamana]. In virecana, the count of purgation (should begin) after the initial two or three [bowel movements containing] feces; in vamana, the count is of the vomitus.  "

text: अथैनं वामितं भूयः स्नेहस्वेदोपपादितम्। श्लेष्मकाले गते ज्ञात्वा कोष्ठं सम्यग्विरेचयेत्॥
en_dmt: "Then, when he has vomited, and oleation and sudation have been performed again, having ascertained that the time for phlegm has passed, one should properly administer a purgative to his bowels.  "

text: बहुपित्तो मृदुः कोष्ठः क्षीरेणापि विरिच्यते। प्रभूतमारुतः क्रूरः कृच्छ्राच्छ्यामादिकैरपि॥
en_dmt: "[If] pitta is abundant, the bowels are soft, and one is purged even by milk, [but if] the wind is excessive and the bowels are hard, [then one is purged] with difficulty even by *śyāmā* and other [purgatives].  "

text: कषायमधुरैः पित्ते विरेकः, कटुकैः कफे। स्निग्धोष्णलवणैर्वायावप्रवृत्तौ तु पाययेत्॥
en_dmt: "A purgative with astringent and sweet substances [should be used] in Pitta; with pungent substances, in Kapha. But if Vāta is aggravated, one should administer [a purgative] with oily, hot, and salty substances.  "

text: उष्णाम्बु, स्वेदयेदस्य पाणितापेन चोदरम्। उत्थानेऽल्पे दिने तस्मिन्भुक्त्वाऽन्येद्युः पुनः पिबेत्॥
en_dmt: "Hot water should be used to foment his abdomen with the warmth of the hand. On that day, when he gets up a little, he should eat, and the next day, he should drink [it] again.  "

text: अदृढस्नेहकोष्ठस्तु पिबेदूर्ध्वं दशाहतः। भूयोऽप्युपस्कृततनुः स्नेहस्वेदैर्विरेचनम्॥ यौगिकं सम्यगालोच्य स्मरन्पूर्वमनुक्रमम्। हृत्कुक्ष्यशुद्धिररुचिरुत्क्लेशः श्लेष्मपित्तयोः॥
en_dmt: "But one whose alimentary canal is not strong in respect of oleation should drink [it] upwards for ten days. Again, when the body has been prepared with oleation and sudation, [one should take] a purgative. Having properly considered the combination, remembering the previous order, [one should proceed]. [The symptoms of improper oleation are] impurity of the heart and abdomen, anorexia, nausea, and [aggravation of] *śleṣma* and *pitta*.  "

text: कण्डूर्विदाहः पिटिकाः पीनसो वातविङ्ग्रहः। अयोगलक्षणं योगो वैपरीत्ये यथोदितात्॥
en_dmt: "Itching, burning sensation, pustules, coryza, and suppression of flatus; non-application of effort is the characteristic, and application of effort is the opposite of what has been stated.  "

text: विट्_पित्तकफवातेषु निःसृतेषु क्रमात्स्रवेत्। निःश्लेष्मपित्तमुदकं श्वेतं कृष्णं सलोहितम्॥ मांसधावनतुल्यं वा मेदः खण्डाभमेव वा। गुदनिःसरणं तृष्णा भ्रमो नेत्रप्रवेशनम्॥ भवन्त्यतिविरिक्तस्य तथाऽतिवमनामयाः। सम्यग्विरिक्तमेनं च वमनोक्तेन योजयेत्॥
en_dmt: "When feces, bile, phlegm, and wind have been expelled, they are gradually discharged. [The vomit] is free of phlegm and bile, watery, white, black, or bloody, Or like meat washings, or like pieces of fat. Prolapse of the anus, thirst, dizziness, and sinking of the eyes occur. These are the diseases of excessive purgation and excessive vomiting. One should treat him, who has been properly purged, in the manner described for emesis.  "

text: धूमवर्ज्येन विधिना ततो वमितवानिव। क्रमेणान्नानि भुञ्जानो भजेत्प्रकृतिभोजनम्॥

text: मन्दवह्निमसंशुद्धमक्षामं दोषदुर्बलम्। अदृष्टजीर्णलिङ्गं च लङ्घयेत्पीतभेषजम्॥
en_dmt: "One should avoid taking medicine when the digestive fire is weak, [the body is] not purified, [one is] emaciated, weak from illness, when the signs of old age are not yet visible, or after purgation.  "

text: स्नेहस्वेदौषधोत्क्लेशसङ्गैरिति न बाध्यते। संयोधनास्रविस्रावस्नेहयोजनलङ्घनैः॥
en_dmt: "It is not contradicted by affection, sweat, medicine, affliction, or association. Nor by battle, the flowing of blood, the oozing of oil, union, or transgression.  "

text: यात्यग्निर्मन्दतां तस्मात् क्रर्म पेयादिमाचरेत्। स्रुताल्पपित्तश्लेष्माणं मद्यपं वातपैत्तिकम्॥
en_dmt: "The *agni* of a person becomes diminished; therefore, [the physician] should implement the *peyādi krama* dietary regimen. [Administer emetics] to a drunkard with little *pitta* and *śleṣma*, or with *vāta-paittika* [disorder].  "

text: पेयां न पाययेत्तेषां तर्पणादिक्रमो हितः। अपक्वं वमनं दोषान् पच्यमानं विरेचनम्॥
en_dmt: "He should not give them *peya*. The order of offering *tarpaṇa*, etc., is beneficial. An undigested substance causes vomiting of the *doṣas*, while a digesting substance causes purgation.  "

text: निर्हरेद्वमनस्यातः पाकं न प्रतिपालयेत्। दुर्बलो बहुदोषश्च दोषपाकेन यः स्वयम्॥
en_dmt: "Therefore, one should not wait for the digestion of emetic medicines. A debilitated person with abundant morbid *doṣas*, [who] is himself [affected] by *doṣa pāka*.  "

en_dmt: "One should offer him food that is purgative. The weak man, previously cleansed, with few doṣas, is emaciated.  "

text: अपरिज्ञातकोष्ठश्च पिबेन्मृद्वल्पमौषधम्। वरं तदसकृत्पीतमन्यथा संशयावहम्॥ हरेद्बहूंश्चलान् दोषानल्पानल्पान् पुनः पुनः। दुर्बलस्य मृदुद्रव्यैरल्पान् संशमयेत्तु तान्॥
en_dmt: "He should drink a mild and small amount of medicine even if the location of the disease is not known. It is better to drink that repeatedly, otherwise it causes doubt. It removes many aggravated *doṣas* that are moving, little by little, again and again. But in the case of a weak person, he should pacify those aggravated *doṣas* with mild substances, in small amounts.  "

text: क्लेशयन्ति चिरं ते हि हन्युर्वैनमनिर्हृताः। मन्दाग्निं क्रूरकोष्ठं च सक्षारलवणैर्घृतैः॥
en_dmt: "For they torment [him] for a long time and would kill him if they were not removed.  [Administer] clarified butter with alkaline substances and salts to one with weak digestion and a hard belly.  "

en_dmt: "Having kindled the fire, one should cleanse [the patient] who has overcome *kapha* and *vāta*, [as well as those] who are accustomed to dry and plentiful food, wind, a cruel stomach, and exercise.  "

text: दीप्ताग्नीनां च भैषज्यमविरेच्यैव जीर्यति। तेभ्यो बस्तिं पुरा दद्यात्ततः स्निग्धं विरेचनम्॥ शकृन्निर्हृत्य वा किञ्चित्तीक्ष्णाभिः फलवर्तिभिः। प्रवृत्तं हि मलं स्निग्धो विरेको निर्हरेत्सुखम्॥
en_dmt: "For those with blazing digestive fire, medicine is digested even without purgation. For them, administer an enema first, then a soothing purgative. Or, after removing some excrement with sharp fruit suppositories, a soothing purgative will easily eliminate the flowing stool.  "

text: विषाभिघातपिटिका-कुष्ठशोफविसर्पिणः। कामलापाण्डुमेहार्तान्नातिस्निग्धान् विशोधयेत्॥
en_dmt: "Those suffering from poisoning, trauma, boils, leprosy, swelling, erysipelas, jaundice, anemia, or diabetes should not be cleansed with excessively unctuous substances.  "

en_dmt: "All those who have been treated with oleation should be purged with emetics and unctuous substances; and again and again, in between, with emetics and other such cleansing actions (karmaṇāṃ vamanādīnām).  "

en_dmt: "One should apply oleation and fomentation, and at the end of oleation, [apply them] for strength, since impurities are dislodged from the body and removed, just as from a garment.  "

text: स्नेहस्वेदैस्तथोत्क्लिष्टः शोध्यते शोधनैर्मलः। स्नेहस्वेदावनभ्यस्य कुर्यात्संशोदनं तु यः॥
en_dmt: "The dirt is softened with the oils and sweat of affection, and then cleansed with purifying agents. He who, without applying oils and sweat, attempts purification...  "
